•Actions  d’ingénierie  de formation,  conception  et amorçage  ;

En quoi  consiste  votre  projet  ? Le projet  QUANTIF  IA a pour  objectif  de tester  la faisabilité  de l’utilisation  de
l’Intelligence  Artificielle  pour quantifier  automatiquement  des informations
présentes  dans  des images  scientifiques  ou industrielles.
Quels  sont  les objectifs  de votre  projet  ? (à quoi  / à qui
va-t-il servir  ? quel  type  de clients ?  combien  de 
personnes  touchées  ? quelles  retombées  sur le
territoire  ?)Le traitement  d’images  est une activité  transverse.  Elle est en lien avec  un
grand  nombre  de domaines  : L’énergie,  l’aéronautique,  la santé,  la chimie,  le 
luxe,  …
Ce projet  participe  activement  à la digitalisation  des entreprises  et à
l’amélioration  des contrôles,  en remplaçant  des verdicts  visuels  « opérateurs 
dépendants  », par des  mesures  fiables  et reproductibles  en s’appuyant  sur
l’Intelligence  Artificielle.
Cette  nouvelle  technologie  sera  utilisée  par de nombreux  acteurs  régionaux 
et internationaux,  notamment  dans  le domaine  de la micro -électronique  et
de l’analyse  géologique  des sols.

Coating
Peintures, vernis, colles et encres sont l’objet de nombreuses contrefaçons et il est difficile d’agréger les chiffres liés à ces différentes fraudes. Ces secteurs sont potentiellement très sensibles à l’authentification (tableaux, papier de sécurité, …)
Cosmétique
Chaque année, dans l’ensemble de l’UE, les ventes de parfums, de produits de maquillage et de produits de soins personnels contrefaits font perdre aux fabricants, aux détaillants et aux distributeurs légitimes, 4,7Mds€, indique un rapport de l’OHMI.

Luxe
Le marché de la mode contrefaite est évalué à 464 Mds$ en 2019 et les pertes de ventes de mode liées aux produits contrefaits ont atteint 26,3 Mds€ dans le monde en 2020.
Agroalimentaire
La Grocery Manufacturers Association estime que la falsification économique et la contrefaçon des produits alimentaires et de consommation mondiaux coûtent à l'industrie 10 à 15 Mds$ par an.
Les secteurs concernés
Pharmaceutique
Vaccins, antirétroviraux, antipaludéens contrefaits : le trafic de faux médicaments est un business lucratif, des centaines de milliers de victimes. Le CA(contrefaçon) est estimé >15% du marché pharmaceutique mondial, soit 100 à 150 Mds$ (une étude du Forum économique mondial).

The parent market of the security paper market is the broader global security solutions and secure printing industry. This expansive industry encompasses a range of products and services designed to ensure the authenticity, integrity, and confidentiality of physical and digital documents. It includes various security features and technologies used in the production of secure documents, anti-counterfeiting measures, brand protection strategies, and the safeguarding of personal and sensitive information. The growth and dynamics of the security paper market are influenced by the developments, regulations, and technological advancements within this larger security solutions industry. As governments, corporations, and institutions continue to prioritize security and combat the rising threat of document fraud and counterfeiting, the demand for sophisticated security features in paper-based documents remains robust, directly impacting the trajectory of the security paper market within the global landscape of security solutions.
15Market Definition
©Exactitude ConsultancyThe security papers market encompasses the production and distribution of specialized paper products designed to prevent counterfeiting, forgery, and unauthorized reproduction. These papers are integral to creating high-security documents, including but not limited to currency notes, passports, identity cards, certificates, legal documents, cheques, and stamps. Security papers are imbued with various features that enhance their security, making them difficult to replicate or alter without detection. The market for security papers is driven by the global need for secure and verifiable documents, a demand that spans across government, banking, legal, and personal documentation to combat fraud and ensure the integrity of important documents. Technological advancements in material science and digital verification methods continue to evolve the market, offering new ways to integrate physical and digital security measures.Parent Market

## Page 30

1. Integration of Advanced Security Features•The integration of sophisticated security features into paper documents continues to be a major trend. This includes the use of color-shifting inks, advanced watermarks, security threads embedded with nano-optics, and holographic elements. These features are becoming increasingly complex, making it harder for counterfeiters to replicate documents accurately.2. Digital and Physical Security Convergence•There's a growing trend towards blending physical security features with digital technologies. QR codes, RFID (Radio-Frequency Identification) chips, and NFC (Near Field Communication) technologies are being integrated into security papers to bridge the gap between physical and digital security. This convergence enables real-time authentication and tracking of documents, enhancing their security manifold.3. Sustainable and Eco-Friendly Materials•As environmental concerns gain traction globally, there's a noticeable shift towards the use of sustainable and eco-friendly materials in the production of security papers. Manufacturers are exploring the use of recycled fibers, reducing the reliance on virgin pulp, and employing eco-friendly manufacturing processes to appeal to environmentally conscious consumers and comply with regulatory standards.4. Personalization and Customization•Customization of security features to meet specific needs of different documents or industries is becoming more common. This trend is driven by the realization that one-size-fits-all security features may not be effective across different types of documents. Customized security features can provide a higher level of protection for sensitive documents.31Global Security Paper Market Trends
©Exactitude Consultancy

## Page 31

5. Increasing Demand for Secure Identification and Travel Documents•With global mobility on the rise, there is an increasing demand for secure identification and travel documents, such as passports and visas. This demand is driving innovation in the security paper market, with governments looking for the most secure and tamper-proof documents to prevent identity theft and fraud.6. Adoption of Blockchain for Document Verification•Blockchain technology is emerging as a tool for enhancing the security of paper documents. By storing the unique identifiers of security features in a blockchain, it becomes nearly impossible to forge or alter documents without detection. This technology is expected to be increasingly adopted for certificates, legal documents, and other high-stakes documents.7. Regulatory and Compliance Pressures•Governments and international bodies are tightening regulations around document security to combat fraud and counterfeiting. This regulatory pressure is prompting organizations and governments to adopt the latest security papers to comply with these new standards, driving market growth.8. Focus on High Durability and Longevity•There is a growing emphasis on the durability and longevity of security papers, especially for documents intended to last several decades, such as land titles, legal documents, and archival papers.  3 Introduction  
The fashion and luxury industry  rely on complex and often geographically fragmented 
value chains . Because of this, it generates many consumers ’ demand s about  
transparency on the social and environmental impact of its products.  
  
Traceability and transparency are key to effectively identifying, preventing , and 
mitigating actual and potential negative impacts, in terms of human rights violations, 
adverse environ mental effects and human health risks.  
  
In view of the evolution of French and European legislation, the growing demands  for 
traceability and the plurality of initiatives broken down by sector (textiles, leather, 
distribution, raw materials, etc.), the French s tate, through the Ministry of the Economy 
and the stakeholders of the Fashion and Luxury Sector Strategic Committee, including 
the DEFI, have included traceability as a strategic axis of the Fashion and Luxury Sector 
Strategic Contract (CSF).   
1) Presentation of the pilot and companies  
a) Context  
i) French and European regulatory developments  
The recent AGEC law and the Climate & Resilience bill change the obligations of 
companies on several important points (environmental labelling , detail of chemical 
substances, etc.).  
  
In order to fulfil these obligations, companies must collect and analyse  data specific to 
their products and value chains.  Their traceability is therefore essential.  
 
ii) Evolution of consumer demands  
Consumer demand for responsible products has increased following the COVID 19 
crisis. The 2020 IFM study , carried out in 5 European countries including France, 
reveals an increase in declarations of intentions to purchase of responsible products to 
reach 6 4% of respondents.  Among the other lessons of this study, there is also a strong 
attention and demand for the traceability and transparency of brands  :  
• 60%of consumers pay attention to Made in  
• 80% are in favour  of imposing Made in on labels  

## Page 4

DISCLAIMER  
This document is a strictly confidential communication to and solely for the use of the recipient and may not be reproduced o r circulated without DEFI prior consent. 
If you are not the intended recipient, you may not disclose or use the informat ion in this documentation in any way.  
 4 iii) The traceabili ty project of the Fashion and Luxury Sector Strategic 
Committee (CSF)  
The CSF traceability project is organized in 2 stages  : exploration and 
experimentation.  The exploration stage was carried out in 2019 -2020 through a “ 
Traceability and CSR performance ”  working group (WG)  . This WG identified solutions 
and proposed to refocus the project on 3 pragmatic and operational collective 
actions  :       
• Participation in the creation of a harmonized traceability standard at 
European level for 2021 by defending its  suitability for SMEs in the 
sector  
• The implementation of traceability pilots to test the solutions adopted by 
the "  Traceability and CSR performance " WG  and find funding for the 
realization of these pilots    
• Structure the sector on the notions of traceab ility and transparency 
through a “  governance / traceability  ” working group.    
  
The CSF is launching the second stage of the traceability project in September 
2021  : experimentation through traceability pilots.   
  
Thus ,  the CSF is launching 4 traceability pilots around 4 sectors  :  
• Linen  
• Apparel  
• Textile  
• Shoe  
b) The objectives of the pilot  
 
Traceability pilots aim to identify the best methodologies and tools to implement 
traceability within the fashion and luxury sector , as quickly as possible ,  and for the 
greatest number of companies.  
  
The “ Apparel  ” pilot has the following specific objectives  :    
  
A. Study the needs of companies in terms of traceability : 
o Context  
o Functional characteristics  
o Constraints  
o Design criterion  
o Communication & transparency

c) Uses of tracea bility in the «  Apparel »  pilot  
There are different uses of traceability.  As part of the " Apparel “ pilot  , here is the list of 
priority uses put forward by companies  (in order of importance)  : 
 
1. Origin of the manufacturing steps  
 
In order to meet consumer demands and anticipate future regulations in this area, the 
chosen solution will make it possible to collect, verify and communicate the origin of the 
manufa cturing stages of Apparel.   
 
2. “Responsible”  claims for raw materials:      
  
The second use case of the pilot is to facilitate the collection & verification of data 
relating to “responsible  materials” claims  . The chosen solution will make it more 
reliable, automated and optimized.    
3. Calculation of the product and organization  environmental impact:    
The traceability solution must facilitate the calculation of the environmental impacts of 
products and organizations.  The collection, verification and sharing of environmental 
activity data is therefore a key point.  
4. Social compliance ma nagement  :  
The traceability solution chosen will make it possible to verify and guarantee good 
working conditions and respect for human rights throughout the value chain.    
  
5. Communications:

Other stakeholders, including financial support, are likely to participate in the pilot

2) The target solution(s)  
a) Technical specific ities  
i) Traceable assets, granularity and identification  
The traceability solution(s) must make it possible to trace the manufacturing (from the 
textile components to the production batch) throughout the textile value chain . This 
means that the solution(s) must be able to trace fib ers, threads, fabrics and finished 
products through textile accessories (buttons, labels, etc. ) .  
  
The solution(s) must be able to manage the transformation of t he various traceable 
assets throughout the textile value chain.  
  
Finally, these traceable assets must be identified by a unique identifier for the production 
batch.  
ii) The perimeter  : entry point and exit point  
 
The scope retained for this pilot is to be able to trace the products from the raw material 
source (field, synthetic fiber factory, collector/ sorter ), to the store.  
  
The actors of the pilot are aware of the complexity, to date, of this objective but wish to 
invest as much as possible in this pilot .   
  
Therefore  the scope of this pilot is divided into two objectives:   
-        Commitment (minimum objective)  : trace up to rank 3, the spinning, of course 
integrating all the subsequent manufacturing stages whether they are subcontracted or 
not.  
-        Target objective:  obtain information from rank 4, aka the production stage of the 
raw material (fiber, soft materials, recycled/upcycl ed materials, etc.)

 8   
Finally, the scope of the pilot concerns most of  the components of the traced product, at 
least the main components representing 80% of the weight of the product.  
  
This Apparel traceability  pilot will be an opportunity for companies  to prepare for the 
application of article 13 of the AGEC law (traceability obligation).  
 
 
iii) Choice of products   
 
Each company will determine an internal perimeter for the pilot representative of their 
reality and based on a reduced number of products/value chains.  
iv) Data to be plotted  
The list of data below is not exhaustive and may be updated according to the 
requirements of the UNECE -CEFACT textile traceability standard as well as other 
sources (PEFCR, etc.).  
• Identification  : legal name, commercial name, address, legal identifier, 
specific identifier (UDI, etc.)   
• Quality  : technical sheet, quality certification, results of quality tests, etc.   
• CSR :  
o Product and manufacturing site certification  
o Specific activity data for environmental impa ct calculation  
This list is not exhaustive and will be the subject of detailed exchange with the chosen 
traceability solution.  
v) Data exchange  
Data exchanges must comply with recognized international data exchange standards, in 
particular the UNECE traceab ility standard.  
 
In the same way, the traceability solution must guarantee the full interoperability of its 
tools to allow and facilitate the exchange of data with other information systems internal 
or external to the company.  
b) Features  
The Apparel  pilot has defined the following needs in terms of the functionality of the 
traceability solution  :  
 
1- Data collection & automa tion

3) Pilot constraints  
The " Apparel  " pilot has several constraints to consider . Here is the li st in order of importance.    

## Page 11

DISCLAIMER  
This document is a strictly confidential communication to and solely for the use of the recipient and may not be reproduced o r circulated without DEFI prior consent. 
If you are not the intended recipient, you may not disclose or use the informat ion in this documentation in any way.  
 11 a) Budget  
The primary goal of the pilot is to test and facilitate the implementation of traceability 
within the French fashion and luxury industry.  The specificity of this pilot is to be the first 
multi -party initiative in France on traceability and organized by the entire sector (CSF).  It 
brings together companies of different sizes, market segments and maturities on the 
subject as well as their value chains.  
  
This pilot is a unique opportunity for companies and for tracea bility solutions to 
participate in the project of the French Fashion and Luxury sector.  
 
This sector pilot requires investment in resources and people from all stakeholders.  The 
traceability solution will therefore have to propose an accessible budget for each type of 
company and which will reflect the capacity of the solution to invest in the traceability 
project of the sector.  
b) User accessibility  
The traceability solution must be  :  
• Easy to use, accessible and efficient  
• Adapted to each type of user in the textile value chain  
• In several languages, at least French and English  
• Available on several types of terminals depending on the uses (computer, 
smartphone, mobile phone)  
c) Legal constraints  
The solution must guarantee compliance with legal requirements, particularly in terms of 
property management and data confidentiality.  
 
Any use other than required by the pilot must be subject to the prior approval of the pilot 
companies and the Steering Committee (COPIL) of the pilot Apparel . 
d) Interop erability of the information systems (IS)  
The solution will have to interact with the IS of the pilot companies as well as the 
suppliers of their value chain.  For this, the solution must guarantee an interoperable and 
preferably international and recognized data exchange standard.  
  
Similarly, the solution must be able to offer connection and exchange interfaces adapted 
to each user company according to its level of equipment and access to networks (web, 
tel, etc.).

 12 e) Privacy and security  
In addition to compli ance with the legal framework around confidentiality, the solution 
must allow its users to manage the confidentiality of the data they own at any time.  
Finally, data security must be guaranteed at all times as well as the security of the 
interfaces with the IS of the pilot companies.  
f) Team and project planning  
In order to better pilot the "  Apparel  " sector pilot, the solution will have to deploy a 
dedicated team capable of managing the pilot's potential workload.    
  
The pilot must be completed no later than the third quarter of 2022.

Naturakem peut faire rédaction de la Fiche de Données de Sécurité (FDS) de cdots (et éventuellement des mélanges si besoin)
La première étape est envoyer un NDA pour pouvoir échanger librement
La rédaction de la fiche sera entre 500 et 1000 euros
Les tests nécessaires pour avoir les donnes sécurité pour la rédaction de la fiche (réalisés par des laboratoires qualifiés) peuvent aller de 3500 à 10 000 euros.
Le délai pour les tests (sensibilisation cutané, irritation cutané et essais in vitro sur peaux de synthèses) et rédaction de la fiche peut aller de 1 à 3 mois.
Pour la rédaction peut-être que l’on pourrait s’appuyer sur les données de la littérature mais si l’on souhaite aller vers le marché cosmétique c’est mieux de faire les essais.
L’obligation Reach s’applique seulement pour une fabrication supérieur à 1 tonne de marqueurs (Naturakem pourrait le faire aussi mais nous discuterons dans un deuxième temps)..
